FILE: cm710740v11.0.txt
DYAD: CHINA-JAPAN
RIVALRY: RIV1296
DISPUTE(S): MID2199 MID1489 MID2200 MID2201 MID2202 MID1486 MID1488 MID1490 MID31 MID2203 MID2204 MID260 MID2205 MID1777 MID2701 MID1810 MID2206 MID2207 MID2208 MID145 MID2209 MID2210 MID40 MID129 MID2211 MID139 MID2212 MID2213 MID616 MID2214 MID157 MID258 MID3208 MID2853 
RIVALRY: RIV11298
DISPUTE(S): MID2966 MID4061 MID4062 MID4180 

PS: 19009999-19510907 0.0 19510908-19610207 -9 19610208-20209999 0.25

PS-UPDATE2020: Conflict over regional issues and dispute over the Senaku islands persist and even worsen as China seeks regional hegemony

PS1800: 18730600-18999999 0.0

PSNOTES: 

For the period 19610208-20069999, the begin date was changed from 19610207 to 19610208 because beginning day of this period was transposed with the ending date of the last period. Therefore, for period 19510908-19610207, end date was changed from 19610208 to 19610207. Begin date is based on February 8, 1961, when China and Japan re-started their trade relations after a 18 months break. 

PS-LAST-CHANGED: 20220324
PS-LAST-CHECKED: 20220324

Territorial-Maritime-Boundary Issues Variables

Pre-1900 MIDs: MID2199 MID1489 MID2200 MID2201 MID2202 MID1486 MID1488 MID1490

WWI MIDs: MID260 MID2205 MID1777 

WWII MIDs: MID258 

MID31 

TERRMID: MID31 3 -- not territory 
TERRMID-CER: MID31 1 -- certain 
TERRMID-NOTES: 

TERRLINK: MID31 3 -- not third party link to territory 
TERRLINK-CER: MID31 1 -- certain 
TERRLINK-NOTES: 

MARITMID: MID31 3 -- not maritime 
MARITMID-CER: MID31 1 -- certain 
MARITMID-NOTES: 

ISLMID: MID31 3 -- not islands 
ISLMID-CER: MID31 1 -- certain 
ISLMID-NOTES: 

CIVWARMID: MID31 1 -- civil war MID
CIVWARMID-CER: MID31 1 -- certain 
CIVWARMID-NOTES: MID31 from Gibler 2018, this is the Boxer Rebellion. In 1900-1901, a militarized group in China attacked Christian missionaries and threatened the economic interests of the US, UK, France, Germany, Austria-Hungary, Italy, Russia, and Japan. Japan, along with the other major powers, intervened to quell the rebellion. Coded civil war MID because this was connected to militarized rebels in China, within this dyad. 

CIVWARLINK: MID31 3 -- not civil war link 
CIVWARLINK-CER: MID31 1 -- certain 
CIVWARLINK-NOTES: 

COUPMID: MID31 3 -- not coup 
COUPMID-CER: MID31 1 -- certain 
COUPMID-NOTES: 

COUPLINK: MID31 3 -- not coup link
COUPLINK-CER: MID31 1 -- certain 
COUPLINK-NOTES: 

MID2203 

TERRMID: MID2203 1 -- territorial MID
TERRMID-CER: MID2203 1 -- certain 
TERRMID-NOTES: MID2203 from Gibler 2018, after the Russo-Japanese War, Japan claimed part of Manchuria and had a railway company there. In 1907, China, after agreeing not to build railways that interfered with Japan's in Manchuria, began secretly planning to build railroads into Manchuria, and Japan issued a series of threats to China. Coded territorial MID because this was connected to a dispute over Manchuria, which Japan was claiming and demanding that China not place railroads there. 

TERRLINK: MID2203 3 -- not third party link to territory 
TERRLINK-CER: MID2203 1 -- certain 
TERRLINK-NOTES: 

MARITMID: MID2203 3 -- not maritime 
MARITMID-CER: MID2203 1 -- certain 
MARITMID-NOTES: 

ISLMID: MID2203 3 -- not islands 
ISLMID-CER: MID2203 1 -- certain 
ISLMID-NOTES: 

CIVWARMID: MID2203 3 -- not civil war 
CIVWARMID-CER: MID2203 1 -- certain 
CIVWARMID-NOTES:

CIVWARLINK: MID2203 3 -- not civil war link 
CIVWARLINK-CER: MID2203 1 -- certain 
CIVWARLINK-NOTES: 

COUPMID: MID2203 3 -- not coup 
COUPMID-CER: MID2203 1 -- certain 
COUPMID-NOTES: 

COUPLINK: MID2203 3 -- not coup link
COUPLINK-CER: MID2203 1 -- certain 
COUPLINK-NOTES: 

MID2204 

TERRMID: MID2204 1 -- territorial MID
TERRMID-CER: MID2204 1 -- certain 
TERRMID-NOTES: MID2204 from Gibler 2018, China was dissatisfied with Japan's control of Manchuria and was seeking to take control of it. In 1909, China signed a railroad agreement with the UK, and Japan considered this an attempt by China to assert control over Manchuria. Japan protested, and the UK mediated an agreement in which China conceded another part of Manchuria to Japan. Coded territorial MID because this was connected to a territorial dispute in Manchuria. 

TERRLINK: MID2204 3 -- not third party link to territory 
TERRLINK-CER: MID2204 1 -- certain 
TERRLINK-NOTES: 

MARITMID: MID2204 3 -- not maritime 
MARITMID-CER: MID2204 1 -- certain 
MARITMID-NOTES: 

ISLMID: MID2204 3 -- not islands 
ISLMID-CER: MID2204 1 -- certain 
ISLMID-NOTES:

CIVWARMID-CER: MID2204 1 -- certain 
CIVWARMID-NOTES:

CIVWARLINK: MID2204 3 -- not civil war link 
CIVWARLINK-CER: MID2204 1 -- certain 
CIVWARLINK-NOTES:

COUPMID-CER: MID2204 1 -- certain

COUPLINK: MID2204 3 -- not coup link

COUPLINK-NOTES: 

MID2701 

TERRMID: MID2701 3 -- not territory
TERRMID-CER: MID2701 1 -- certain 
TERRMID-NOTES: 

TERRLINK: MID2701 1 -- third party link to territorial MID
TERRLINK-CER: MID2701 3 -- uncertain 
TERRLINK-NOTES: MID2701 from Gibler, Miller and Little 2016, when the Allies intervened in the Russian Civil War, China decided to take advantage by asserting its right to navigate the Amur River, a river boundary between China and Russia that Russia controlled. Russia threatened China, but China sailed through anyway. Russia fired upon China. Coded third party link to territorial MID because this was connected to a dispute over a river boundary. Coded uncertain because GML do not consider this to be a MID between Japan and China. 

MARITMID: MID2701 3 -- not maritime 
MARITMID-CER: MID2701 1 -- certain 
MARITMID-NOTES: 

ISLMID: MID2701 3 -- not islands 
ISLMID-CER: MID2701 1 -- certain 
ISLMID-NOTES: 

CIVWARMID: MID2701 3 -- not civil war
CIVWARMID-CER: MID2701 1 -- certain 
CIVWARMID-NOTES: 

CIVWARLINK: MID2701 1 -- civil war link MID
CIVWARLINK-CER: MID2701 3 -- uncertain 
CIVWARLINK-NOTES: MID2701 coded civil war link MID because this MID was connected to the Russian Civil War, outside this dyad. Coded uncertain because GML recommend this MID between China and Japan be dropped, since Japan and China did not threaten or use force against each other.

COUPMID: MID2701 3 -- not coup 
COUPMID-CER: MID2701 1 -- certain 
COUPMID-NOTES: 

COUPLINK: MID2701 3 -- not coup link
COUPLINK-CER: MID2701 1 -- certain 
COUPLINK-NOTES: 

MID1810 

TERRMID: MID1810 3 -- not territory 
TERRMID-CER: MID1810 1 -- certain 
TERRMID-NOTES: 

TERRLINK: MID1810 3 -- not third party link to territory 
TERRLINK-CER: MID1810 1 -- certain 
TERRLINK-NOTES: 

MARITMID: MID1810 3 -- not maritime 
MARITMID-CER: MID1810 1 -- certain 
MARITMID-NOTES: 

ISLMID: MID1810 3 -- not islands 
ISLMID-CER: MID1810 1 -- certain 
ISLMID-NOTES: 

CIVWARMID: MID1810 3 -- not civil war 
CIVWARMID-CER: MID1810 1 -- certain 
CIVWARMID-NOTES: MID1810 from Gibler 2018, in 1919 Japan sent ships to China, claiming to want to protect Japanese nationals in Fuchow, China amid domestic unrest there. Japan ended up arresting several Chinese civilians. Coded not civil war because there was no militarized rebel activity in Fuchow. The NYT story describing the incident mentions some domestic unrest (1/4/1920), but neither it nor Gibler 2018 mentions rebel groups, and Japan did not engage any rebels. 

CIVWARLINK: MID1810 3 -- not civil war link 
CIVWARLINK-CER: MID1810 1 -- certain 
CIVWARLINK-NOTES: 

COUPMID: MID1810 3 -- not coup 
COUPMID-CER: MID1810 1 -- certain 
COUPMID-NOTES: 

COUPLINK: MID1810 3 -- not coup link
COUPLINK-CER: MID1810 1 -- certain 
COUPLINK-NOTES: 

MID2206 

TERRMID: MID2206 1 -- territorial MID
TERRMID-CER: MID2206 1 -- certain 
TERRMID-NOTES: MID2206 from Gibler 2018, in 1920 Japan was still in Manchuria, and China was still trying to regain control over Manchuria. China refused to grant additional concessions within the Treaty of Versailles to Japan, and Japan refused to return railways it was supposed to give to China. China demanded Japanese troops leave the territory, and Japan refused. Coded territorial MID because this was connected to a territorial dispute. 

TERRLINK: MID2206 3 -- not third party link to territory 
TERRLINK-CER: MID2206 1 -- certain 
TERRLINK-NOTES:

MID2207 

TERRMID: MID2207 1 -- territorial MID
TERRMID-CER: MID2207 1 -- certain 
TERRMID-NOTES: MID2207 from Gibler 2018, in 1925 Japan took advantage of the civil war in China to move troops into Manchuria so it could press its claim there. Coded territorial MID because this was connected to a territorial dispute.

MID2208 

TERRMID: MID2208 3 -- not territory 
TERRMID-CER: MID2208 1 -- certain 
TERRMID-NOTES: 

TERRLINK: MID2208 3 -- not third party link to territory 
TERRLINK-CER: MID2208 1 -- certain 
TERRLINK-NOTES: 

MARITMID: MID2208 3 -- not maritime 
MARITMID-CER: MID2208 1 -- certain 
MARITMID-NOTES: MID2208 from cm002710 narrative, the Great Powers (Germany, Japan, France, UK, US, Italy, Russia) demanded that China remove mines it had placed in the Dagu Harbor, as that harbor provided access to a major Chinese river. Those countries jointly threatened China, triggering this MID. China exchanged naval fire with Japan as part of this incident. Coded not maritime because the maritime boundary was not disputed between China and Japan. 

ISLMID: MID2208 3 -- not islands 
ISLMID-CER: MID2208 1 -- certain 
ISLMID-NOTES: 

CIVWARMID: MID2208 3 -- not civil war 
CIVWARMID-CER: MID2208 1 -- certain 
CIVWARMID-NOTES:

CIVWARLINK: MID2208 3 -- not civil war link 
CIVWARLINK-CER: MID2208 1 -- certain 
CIVWARLINK-NOTES:

COUPMID-CER: MID2208 1 -- certain

COUPLINK: MID2208 3 -- not coup link

COUPLINK-NOTES: 

MID145 

TERRMID: MID145 3 -- not territory 
TERRMID-CER: MID145 1 -- certain 
TERRMID-NOTES: 

TERRLINK: MID145 3 -- not third party link to territory 
TERRLINK-CER: MID145 1 -- certain 
TERRLINK-NOTES: 

MARITMID: MID145 3 -- not maritime 
MARITMID-CER: MID145 1 -- certain 
MARITMID-NOTES: MID145 involved naval shelling, but was not connected to any maritime claims. See CIVWARMID. 

ISLMID: MID145 3 -- not islands 
ISLMID-CER: MID145 1 -- certain 
ISLMID-NOTES: 

CIVWARMID: MID145 1 -- civil war MID
CIVWARMID-CER: MID145 1 -- certain 
CIVWARMID-NOTES: MID145 from Gibler 2018 and cm002710 narrative, this is a naval incident involving the US, UK, France, Spain, Portugal, Italy, and Japan vs. China that occurred February and March 1927. China had been divided along Communist and KMT (led by Chiang Kai-Shek, an anti-communist) fighting for years and would continue until 1949 as the Chinese Civil War. This MID occurred when fighting broke out in Shanghai and Nanking, causing US and UK naval and ground forces to be increased at those locations. Some shelling of Chinese territory occurred to protect US and UK interests. Japan placed warships near Shanghai and Chungking. Coded civil war MID because militarized factions in China broke out into fighting, triggering this MID. 

CIVWARLINK: MID145 3 -- not civil war link 
CIVWARLINK-CER: MID145 1 -- certain 
CIVWARLINK-NOTES: 

COUPMID: MID145 3 -- not coup 
COUPMID-CER: MID145 1 -- certain 
COUPMID-NOTES: 

COUPLINK: MID145 3 -- not coup link
COUPLINK-CER: MID145 1 -- certain 
COUPLINK-NOTES:

CIVWARMID: MID2209 1 -- civil war MID
CIVWARMID-CER: MID2209 1 -- certain 
CIVWARMID-NOTES: MID2209 from Gibler 2018, during the Chinese Civil War, a Chinese mob attacked a Japanese section of Hankow, prompting Japan to deploy troops to protect Japanese nationals. Coded civil war MID because this was connected to the Chinese Civil War.

MID2910 

TERRMID: MID2910 3 -- not territory 
TERRMID-CER: MID2910 3 -- uncertain 
TERRMID-NOTES: MID2910 from Gibler, Miller, and Little 2016, USSR claimed that US planes buzzed a Soviet ship. Coded not territory because this was not connected to a boundary dispute, and coded uncertain because GML do not consider China and Japan to be parties to this dispute, and they recommend the case be dropped since it was not a show of force.

MID40 

TERRMID: MID40 1 -- territorial MID
TERRMID-CER: MID40 1 -- certain 
TERRMID-NOTES: MID40 this was connected to Manchuria, a territorial dispute between China and Japan. 

TERRLINK: MID40 3 -- not third party link to territory 
TERRLINK-CER: MID40 1 -- certain 
TERRLINK-NOTES: 

MARITMID: MID40 3 -- not maritime 
MARITMID-CER: MID40 1 -- certain 
MARITMID-NOTES: 

ISLMID: MID40 3 -- not islands 
ISLMID-CER: MID40 1 -- certain 
ISLMID-NOTES: 

CIVWARMID: MID40 1 -- civil war MID
CIVWARMID-CER: MID40 1 -- certain 
CIVWARMID-NOTES: MID40 from Gibler 2018, in 1928 Japan provided support for a Chinese warlord to fight against Chinah Kai-Shek and the nationalists in the Chinese Civil War. Japan was trying to prevent the nationalists from occupying Manchuria. Coded civil war MID because this was connected to the Chinese Civil War.

MID129 

TERRMID: MID129 1 -- territorial MID
TERRMID-CER: MID129 1 -- certain 
TERRMID-NOTES: MID129 from Gibler 2018, this is the second Sino-Japanese War. A Japanese railroad was blown up, and Japan used this as a pretense to invade Manchuria, seeking to take control of it and sparking a war. Japan defeated the Chinese troops. Coded territorial MID because this was connected to a territorial dispute in Manchuria. 

TERRLINK: MID129 3 -- not third party link to territory 
TERRLINK-CER: MID129 1 -- certain 
TERRLINK-NOTES: 

MARITMID: MID129 3 -- not maritime 
MARITMID-CER: MID129 1 -- certain 
MARITMID-NOTES: 

ISLMID: MID129 3 -- not islands 
ISLMID-CER: MID129 1 -- certain 
ISLMID-NOTES: 

CIVWARMID: MID129 1 -- civil war MID
CIVWARMID-CER: MID129 1 -- certain 
CIVWARMID-NOTES: MID129 per Gibler 2018, Japan was partly motivated by the civil conflict occurring in China, which was tying up China's military resources. 

CIVWARLINK: MID129 3 -- not civil war link 
CIVWARLINK-CER: MID129 1 -- certain 
CIVWARLINK-NOTES:

COUPLINK-NOTES: 

MID2211 

TERRMID: MID2211 1 -- territorial MID
TERRMID-CER: MID2211 1 -- certain 
TERRMID-NOTES: MID2211 from Gibler 2018, in 1933 Japan moved in to Mongolia to claim territory in a westward expansion. Japan occupied several pieces of territory within Mongolia, and local Chinese militias assembled to resist the Japanese, unsuccessfully. Coded territorial MID because this was connected to a territorial dispute. 

TERRLINK: MID2211 3 -- not third party link to territory 
TERRLINK-CER: MID2211 1 -- certain 
TERRLINK-NOTES: 

MARITMID: MID2211 3 -- not maritime 
MARITMID-CER: MID2211 1 -- certain 
MARITMID-NOTES: 

ISLMID: MID2211 3 -- not islands 
ISLMID-CER: MID2211 1 -- certain 
ISLMID-NOTES: 

CIVWARMID: MID2211 1 -- civil war MID
CIVWARMID-CER: MID2211 1 -- certain 
CIVWARMID-NOTES: MID2211 coded civil war MID because the local militias were not Chinese government forces, and the Chinese government rejected them as legitimate forces to fight the Japanese. This makes the Chinese militias a militarized rebel group. 

CIVWARLINK: MID2211 3 -- not civil war link 
CIVWARLINK-CER: MID2211 1 -- certain 
CIVWARLINK-NOTES: 

COUPMID: MID2211 3 -- not coup 
COUPMID-CER: MID2211 1 -- certain 
COUPMID-NOTES: 

COUPLINK: MID2211 3 -- not coup link
COUPLINK-CER: MID2211 1 -- certain 
COUPLINK-NOTES: 

MID139 

TERRMID: MID139 1 -- territorial MID
TERRMID-CER: MID139 1 -- certain 
TERRMID-NOTES: MID139 from Gibler 2018, Japan was occupying territory in China. In 1935, Chinese soldiers invaded, and Japan responded with an assault. Japan added more territory to the area it controlled. Coded territorial MID because this was connected to a territorial dispute. 

TERRLINK: MID139 3 -- not third party link to territory 
TERRLINK-CER: MID139 1 -- certain 
TERRLINK-NOTES: 

MARITMID: MID139 3 -- not maritime 
MARITMID-CER: MID139 1 -- certain 
MARITMID-NOTES: 

ISLMID: MID139 3 -- not islands 
ISLMID-CER: MID139 1 -- certain 
ISLMID-NOTES: 

CIVWARMID: MID139 3 -- not civil war 
CIVWARMID-CER: MID139 1 -- certain 
CIVWARMID-NOTES: MID139 there is no indication in Gibler 2018, cm narrative, or news coverage of this MID that suggests a connection to the ongoing civil conflict in China.

CIVWARLINK: MID139 3 -- not civil war link 
CIVWARLINK-CER: MID139 1 -- certain

COUPLINK-NOTES: 

MID2212 

TERRMID: MID2212 1 -- territorial MID
TERRMID-CER: MID2212 1 -- certain 
TERRMID-NOTES: MID2212 from Gibler 2018, Japan was controlling territory in Mongolia, and China sought to take control of it. Japan also wanted to expand its territory in Mongolia, and in 1934, they invaded Charar province. A clash between Japan and Chinese forces occurred. Coded territorial MID because this was connected to a territorial dispute. 

TERRLINK: MID2212 3 -- not third party link to territory 
TERRLINK-CER: MID2212 1 -- certain 
TERRLINK-NOTES: 

MARITMID: MID2212 3 -- not maritime 
MARITMID-CER: MID2212 1 -- certain

CIVWARMID: MID2212 3 -- not civil war 
CIVWARMID-CER: MID2212 1 -- certain 
CIVWARMID-NOTES: MID2212 there is no indication in cm narrative, Gibler 2018, or news coverage of this MID that this was connected to the ongoing civil conflict in China. 

CIVWARLINK: MID2212 3 -- not civil war link 
CIVWARLINK-CER: MID2212 1 -- certain

MID2213 

TERRMID: MID2213 1 -- territorial MID
TERRMID-CER: MID2213 3 -- uncertain 
TERRMID-NOTES: MID2213 from Gibler, Miller, and Little 2016, this MID should be included in MID2212 due to temporal overlap. It is another clash over control of Manchuria. Coded territorial MID because this was connected to a territorial dispute, and coded uncertain because GML recommend ths case be dropped.

COUPLINK-NOTES: 

MID616 

TERRMID: MID616 1 -- territorial MID
TERRMID-CER: MID616 1 -- certain 
TERRMID-NOTES: MID616 from Gibler 2018, Japan threatened to break off the territory it was controlling from China if China did not concede to Japan's demands that China move closer politically, which likely meant more favorable economic relations with Japan. China mobilized an army in response. Coded territorial MID because this was connected to a territorial dispute. 

TERRLINK: MID616 3 -- not third party link to territory 
TERRLINK-CER: MID616 1 -- certain 
TERRLINK-NOTES: 

MARITMID: MID616 3 -- not maritime 
MARITMID-CER: MID616 1 -- certain 
MARITMID-NOTES: 

ISLMID: MID616 3 -- not islands 
ISLMID-CER: MID616 1 -- certain 
ISLMID-NOTES: 

CIVWARMID: MID616 3 -- not civil war 
CIVWARMID-CER: MID616 1 -- certain 
CIVWARMID-NOTES: MID616 there is no indication in cm narrative, Gibler 2018, or news coverage of this MID that this was connected to the ongoing civil conflict in China. 

CIVWARLINK: MID616 3 -- not civil war link 
CIVWARLINK-CER: MID616 1 -- certain 
CIVWARLINK-NOTES: 

COUPMID: MID616 3 -- not coup 
COUPMID-CER: MID616 1 -- certain 
COUPMID-NOTES: 

COUPLINK: MID616 3 -- not coup link
COUPLINK-CER: MID616 1 -- certain 
COUPLINK-NOTES: 

MID2214 

TERRMID: MID2214 1 -- territorial MID
TERRMID-CER: MID2214 1 -- certain 
TERRMID-NOTES: MID2214 from Gibler 2018, in 1936 the Chinese government was fighting against a communist uprising, and Japan was expanding its territorial control in northern China near Manchuria and Mongolia. Japan deployed warships in response to its citizens getting killed in protests, and clashes followed. Coded territorial MID because this was connected to a territorial dispute. 

TERRLINK: MID2214 3 -- not third party link to territory 
TERRLINK-CER: MID2214 1 -- certain 
TERRLINK-NOTES: 

MARITMID: MID2214 3 -- not maritime 
MARITMID-CER: MID2214 1 -- certain 
MARITMID-NOTES: 

ISLMID: MID2214 3 -- not islands 
ISLMID-CER: MID2214 1 -- certain 
ISLMID-NOTES: 

CIVWARMID: MID2214 1 -- civil war MID
CIVWARMID-CER: MID2214 1 -- certain 
CIVWARMID-NOTES: MID2214 coded civil war MID because this MID involved the Chinese government fighting against the communist groups that would eventually participate in the later Chinese Civil war. Their uprising encouraged Japan to expand its territorial control. 

CIVWARLINK: MID2214 3 -- not civil war link 
CIVWARLINK-CER: MID2214 1 -- certain 
CIVWARLINK-NOTES: 

COUPMID: MID2214 3 -- not coup 
COUPMID-CER: MID2214 1 -- certain 
COUPMID-NOTES: 

COUPLINK: MID2214 3 -- not coup link
COUPLINK-CER: MID2214 1 -- certain 
COUPLINK-NOTES: 

MID3208 

TERRMID: MID3208 3 -- not territory 
TERRMID-CER: MID3208 1 -- certain 
TERRMID-NOTES: 

TERRLINK: MID3208 3 -- not third party link to territory 
TERRLINK-CER: MID3208 1 -- certain 
TERRLINK-NOTES: 

MARITMID: MID3208 1 -- maritime MID
MARITMID-CER: MID3208 1 -- certain 
MARITMID-NOTES: MID3208 from cm narrative and Gibler 2018, Japan and China disputed a maritime boundary and access to fishing in the waters. In 1953, Chinese patrol boats fired on Japanese fishing boats and seized one trawler. China fired on a Japanese patrol boat on a separate occasion. Coded maritime boundary because this was connected to a maritime dispute. 

ISLMID: MID3208 3 -- not islands 
ISLMID-CER: MID3208 1 -- certain 
ISLMID-NOTES:

CIVWARMID-CER: MID3208 1 -- certain

TERRLINK-NOTES: 

MARITMID: MID2853 1 -- maritime MID
MARITMID-CER: MID2853 1 -- certain 
MARITMID-NOTES: MID2853 from Gibler 2018 and cm narrative, in 1958 China attacked several Japanese fishing boats in disputed waters. Coded maritime MID because this was connected to a maritime dispute. 

ISLMID: MID2853 3 -- not islands 
ISLMID-CER: MID2853 1 -- certain

MID2966 

TERRMID: MID2966 3 -- not territory 
TERRMID-CER: MID2966 1 -- certain 
TERRMID-NOTES: 

TERRLINK: MID2966 3 -- not third party link to territory 
TERRLINK-CER: MID2966 1 -- certain 
TERRLINK-NOTES: 

MARITMID: MID2966 1 -- maritime MID
MARITMID-CER: MID2966 3 -- uncertain 
MARITMID-NOTES: MID4061 The Senkaku Islands were disputed due to their maritime boundary implications. The maritime possessions motivate the islands dispute between these countries. Coded uncertain because GML recommend this case be dropped since it does not amount to a MID. 

ISLMID: MID2966 1 -- islands MID
ISLMID-CER: MID2966 3 -- uncertain 
ISLMID-NOTES: MID2966 from Gibler, Miller, and Little 2016, many Chinese boats anchored around the Senkaku Islands, islands which were disputed between China and Japan, and the crew began shouting that the islands belonged to China. Coded islands MID because this was connected to disputed islands, and coded uncertain because GML recommend this case be dropped since it does not amount to a MID. 

CIVWARMID: MID2966 3 -- not civil war 
CIVWARMID-CER: MID2966 1 -- certain 
CIVWARMID-NOTES:

CIVWARLINK: MID2966 3 -- not civil war link

COUPLINK-CER: MID2966 1 -- certain

MARITMID: MID4061 1 -- maritime MID
MARITMID-CER: MID4061 1 -- certain 
MARITMID-NOTES: MID4061 coded maritime MID because the Senkaku Islands were disputed due to their maritime boundary implications. The maritime possessions motivate the islands dispute between these countries.

ISLMID: MID4061 1 -- islands MID
ISLMID-CER: MID4061 1 -- certain 
ISLMID-NOTES: MID4061 from Gibler 2018, in 1995 China violated Japanese airspace over the dipsuted Senkaku Islands, and Japan scrambled fighters. Coded islands MID because this was connected to disputed islands.

ISLMID-CER: MID4062 1 -- certain 
ISLMID-NOTES: MID4062 from Gibler 2018, in 1996 a Japanese nationalist group built a lighthouse on the disputed Senkaku Islands, prompting both China and Japan to deploy naval vessels to stake claims to the islands. Coded islands MID because this was connected to a dispute over the Senkaku islands.

MID4445 

TERRMID: MID4445 3 -- not territory 
TERRMID-CER: MID4445 1 -- certain 
TERRMID-NOTES: MID4445 from Gibler 2018, in 2002 Chinese authorities forced their way into a Japanese consulate to arrest North Korean asylum-seekers. Coded not territory because this was connected to China attempting to return refugees to North Korea and not to a boundary dispute.

TERRLINK-CER: MID4457 1 -- certain

MARITMID: MID4457 1 -- maritime MID
MARITMID-CER: MID4457 1 -- certain 
MARITMID-NOTES: MID4457 coded maritime MID because the Senkaku Islands were disputed due to their maritime boundary implications. The maritime possessions motivate the islands dispute between these countries.

ISLMID: MID4457 1 -- islands MID
ISLMID-CER: MID4457 1 -- certain 
ISLMID-NOTES: MID4457 from Gibler 2018, in 2003-2004 Japanese forces turned away Chinese boats attempting to assert control over the disputed Senkaku Islands. Coded islands MID because this was connected to an islands dispute.

CIVWARMID-CER: MID4457 1 -- certain

MID4467 

TERRMID: MID4467 3 -- not territory 
TERRMID-CER: MID4467 1 -- certain 
TERRMID-NOTES: 

TERRLINK: MID4467 3 -- not third party link to territory 
TERRLINK-CER: MID4467 1 -- certain 
TERRLINK-NOTES: 

MARITMID: MID4467 3 -- not maritime 
MARITMID-CER: MID4467 1 -- certain 
MARITMID-NOTES: MID4467 from cm narrative and Gibler 2018, in 2004 a Chinese submarine entered Japanese waters and was chased off by Japanese naval forces. Coded not maritime because China did not dispute that it was in Japan's waters, and it was therefore not in disputed waters. 

ISLMID: MID4467 3 -- not islands 
ISLMID-CER: MID4467 1 -- certain 
ISLMID-NOTES: 

CIVWARMID: MID4467 3 -- not civil war 
CIVWARMID-CER: MID4467 1 -- certain 
CIVWARMID-NOTES:

COUPMID-CER: MID4467 1 -- certain 
COUPMID-NOTES: 

COUPLINK: MID4467 3 -- not coup link
COUPLINK-CER: MID4467 1 -- certain 
COUPLINK-NOTES: 

MID4472 

TERRMID: MID4472 3 -- not territory 
TERRMID-CER: MID4472 1 -- certain 
TERRMID-NOTES: 

TERRLINK: MID4472 3 -- not third party link to territory 
TERRLINK-CER: MID4472 1 -- certain 
TERRLINK-NOTES: 

MARITMID: MID4472 1 -- maritime MID
MARITMID-CER: MID4472 1 -- certain 
MARITMID-NOTES: MID4472 from Gibler 2018, in 2005 China deployed naval forces to the East China Sea to an area disputed by Japan. The area is rich in natural resources. Coded maritime MID because this was connected to a maritime dispute. 

ISLMID: MID4472 3 -- not islands 
ISLMID-CER: MID4472 1 -- certain 
ISLMID-NOTES: MID4472 the Senkaku Islands are the disputed islands in this area. The islands are disputed due to natural resource reserves in the waters of the East China Sea. The islands dispute is therefore motivated by the maritime dispute in the East China Sea. Since the islands dispute does not motivate the maritime dispute, hoever, this is coded not islands here. 

CIVWARMID: MID4472 3 -- not civil war 
CIVWARMID-CER: MID4472 1 -- certain 
CIVWARMID-NOTES:

CIVWARLINK: MID4472 3 -- not civil war link 
CIVWARLINK-CER: MID4472 1 -- certain 
CIVWARLINK-NOTES: 

COUPMID: MID4472 3 -- not coup 
COUPMID-CER: MID4472 1 -- certain 
COUPMID-NOTES: 

COUPLINK: MID4472 3 -- not coup link
COUPLINK-CER: MID4472 1 -- certain 
COUPLINK-NOTES: 

MID4478 

TERRMID: MID4478 3 -- not territory 
TERRMID-CER: MID4478 1 -- certain 
TERRMID-NOTES: 

TERRLINK: MID4478 1 -- third party link to territorial MID
TERRLINK-CER: MID4478 1 -- certain 
TERRLINK-NOTES: MID4478 this MID involves China using a show of force against Taiwan as part of their dispute over control of all of Chinese territory. This is therefore linked to that territorial MID. 

MARITMID: MID4478 1 -- maritime MID
MARITMID-CER: MID4478 1 -- certain 
MARITMID-NOTES: MID4478 from Gibler 2018, in 2007 China sailed destroyers through Taiwanese and Japanese waters as a show of strength. Coded maritime MID because China and Japan had a maritime dispute in the East China Sea, the waters that China traveled through (the East China Sea lies between China and Japan). 

ISLMID: MID4478 3 -- not islands 
ISLMID-CER: MID4478 1 -- certain 
ISLMID-NOTES: MID4478 the Senkaku Islands are the disputed islands in this area. The islands are disputed due to natural resource reserves in the waters of the East China Sea. The islands dispute is therefore motivated by the maritime dispute in the East China Sea. Since the islands dispute does not motivate the maritime dispute, however, this is coded not islands here. 

CIVWARMID: MID4478 1 -- civil war MID
CIVWARMID-CER: MID4478 1 -- certain 
CIVWARMID-NOTES: MID4478 coded civil war MID because the China/Taiwan dispute has a civil war element, and China is within this dyad. 

CIVWARLINK: MID4478 1 -- civil war link 
CIVWARLINK-CER: MID4478 1 -- certain 
CIVWARLINK-NOTES: MID4478 coded civil war link because the China/Taiwan dispute has a civil war element, and Taiwan is outside this dyad. 

COUPMID: MID4478 3 -- not coup 
COUPMID-CER: MID4478 1 -- certain 
COUPMID-NOTES: 

COUPLINK: MID4478 3 -- not coup link
COUPLINK-CER: MID4478 1 -- certain 
COUPLINK-NOTES: 

MID4489 

TERRMID: MID4489 3 -- not territory 
TERRMID-CER: MID4489 1 -- certain 
TERRMID-NOTES: 

TERRLINK: MID4489 3 -- not third party link to territory 
TERRLINK-CER: MID4489 1 -- certain 
TERRLINK-NOTES: 

MARITMID: MID4489 3 -- not maritime 
MARITMID-CER: MID4489 1 -- certain 
MARITMID-NOTES: MID4489 from cm narrative and Gibler 2018, in 2010 China buzzed a Japanese naval vessel in Japanese territorial waters near Okinawa. Coded not maritime because, although China and Japan disputed a maritme boundary in the East China Sea, there is no indication that this incident was connected to that dispute. It did not occur in disputed waters, and it was seemingly part of a pattern of increased Chinese aggression throughout the region toward many other countries (Foreign Policy 2010). 

ISLMID: MID4489 3 -- not islands 
ISLMID-CER: MID4489 1 -- certain 
ISLMID-NOTES: 

CIVWARMID: MID4489 3 -- not civil war 
CIVWARMID-CER: MID4489 1 -- certain 
CIVWARMID-NOTES:

CIVWARLINK: MID4489 3 -- not civil war link 
CIVWARLINK-CER: MID4489 1 -- certain 
CIVWARLINK-NOTES: 

COUPMID: MID4489 3 -- not coup 
COUPMID-CER: MID4489 1 -- certain 
COUPMID-NOTES: 

COUPLINK: MID4489 3 -- not coup link
COUPLINK-CER: MID4489 1 -- certain 
COUPLINK-NOTES: 

MID4491 

TERRMID: MID4491 3 -- not territory 
TERRMID-CER: MID4491 1 -- certain 
TERRMID-NOTES: 

TERRLINK: MID4491 3 -- not third party link to territory 
TERRLINK-CER: MID4491 1 -- certain 
TERRLINK-NOTES: 

MARITMID: MID4491 1 -- maritime MID
MARITMID-CER: MID4491 1 -- certain 
MARITMID-NOTES: MID4491 from Gibler 2018, in 2010 Japan and China exchanged shows of force in disputed waters near the Senkaku Islands. The waters around the Senkaku Islands contained oil reserves claimed by both countries. Coded maritime MID beacuse this was connected to a maritime dispute.

ISLMID: MID4491 1 -- islands MID
ISLMID-CER: MID4491 1 -- certain 
ISLMID-NOTES: MID4491 this MID also involved the disputed Sentaku Islands, which are claimed by both countries due to maritime boundary implications for the country controlling the islands. 

CIVWARMID: MID4491 3 -- not civil war 
CIVWARMID-CER: MID4491 1 -- certain 
CIVWARMID-NOTES:

CIVWARLINK: MID4491 3 -- not civil war link 
CIVWARLINK-CER: MID4491 1 -- certain 
CIVWARLINK-NOTES: 

COUPMID: MID4491 3 -- not coup 
COUPMID-CER: MID4491 1 -- certain 
COUPMID-NOTES: 

COUPLINK: MID4491 3 -- not coup link
COUPLINK-CER: MID4491 1 -- certain 
COUPLINK-NOTES: 

MID157 

TERRMID: MID157 1 -- territorial MID
TERRMID-CER: MID157 1 -- certain 
TERRMID-NOTES: MID157 from Gibler 2018, this is the Third Sino-Japanese War from 1937-1945. Japan had extensive territorial possessions (claims) in China, and a clash between Chinese and Japanese forces escalated into a war over Japan's territorial holdings. Coded territorial MID because this was a war over Japanese claims on Chinese territory. 

TERRLINK: MID157 3 -- not third party link to territory 
TERRLINK-CER: MID157 1 -- certain 
TERRLINK-NOTES: 

MARITMID: MID157 3 -- not maritime 
MARITMID-CER: MID157 1 -- certain 
MARITMID-NOTES: 

ISLMID: MID157 3 -- not islands 
ISLMID-CER: MID157 1 -- certain 
ISLMID-NOTES: 

CIVWARMID: MID157 3 -- not civil war 
CIVWARMID-CER: MID157 1 -- certain 
CIVWARMID-NOTES:

CIVWARLINK: MID157 3 -- not civil war link 
CIVWARLINK-CER: MID157 1 -- certain 
CIVWARLINK-NOTES: 

COUPMID: MID157 3 -- not coup 
COUPMID-CER: MID157 1 -- certain 
COUPMID-NOTES: 

COUPLINK: MID157 3 -- not coup link
COUPLINK-CER: MID157 1 -- certain 
COUPLINK-NOTES: 

MID4 2002-2010:

MID4445
rivalry=710740 nationa=CHINA nationb=JAPAN MID4445 20020508-20020508 
 revtype1a=POLICY revtype2a=NOT APPLICABLE fatala=NONE fatalpa=0 lhosta=DISPLAY OF FORCE 
 revtype1b=NOT APPLICABLE revtype2b=NOT APPLICABLE fatalb=NONE fatalpb=0 lhostb=
NO MILITARIZED ACTION 

Chinese military authorities forced their way into a Japanese consulate in northeast China in order to detain several North Koreans seeking asylum. The North Koreans were returned to North Korea. First day of dispute was on 5/8/2002 and last day of dispute was on 5/8/2002.

MID4457
rivalry=710740 nationa=JAPAN nationb=CHINA MID4457 20030623-20040327 
 revtype1a=POLICY revtype2a=NOT APPLICABLE fatala=NONE fatalpa=0 lhosta=USE OF FORCE 
 revtype1b=NOT APPLICABLE revtype2b=NOT APPLICABLE fatalb=NONE fatalpb=0 lhostb=
NO MILITARIZED ACTION 

The disputed Senkaku (Diaoyu) Islands were a source of tension for China and Japan. Japan asserted its claim over the islands by dispatching several coast guard vessels and planes to the island to prevent Chinese activists from landing on it, regularly patrolling the waters just outside of what is conventionally seen as the extent of Chinese territorial waters. In one particular incident, Japanese ships and planes attacked two Chinese fishing boats near the islands. First day of dispute was on 6/23/2003 and last day of dispute was 3/27/2004.

MID4467
rivalry=710740 nationa=CHINA nationb=JAPAN MID4467 20041110-20041110 
 revtype1a=NOT APPLICABLE revtype2a=NOT APPLICABLE fatala=NONE fatalpa=0 lhosta=DISPLAY OF FORCE 
 revtype1b=NOT APPLICABLE revtype2b=NOT APPLICABLE fatalb=NONE fatalpb=0
lhostb=DISPLAY OF FORCE 

Japanese naval forces went on full alert when they detected an unidentified nuclear submarine operating in Japanese waters. The sub was determined to be of Chinese origin, which China later corroborated. Japanese naval forces followed the Chinese sub until it left Japanese waters. First day of dispute was on 11/10/2004 and last day of dispute was on 11/10/2004.

MID4472
rivalry=710740 nationa=CHINA nationb=JAPAN MID4472 20050909-20051111 
 revtype1a=NOT APPLICABLE revtype2a=NOT APPLICABLE fatala=NONE fatalpa=0 lhosta=DISPLAY OF FORCE 
 revtype1b=NOT APPLICABLE revtype2b=NOT APPLICABLE fatalb=NONE fatalpb=0
lhostb=NO MILITARIZED ACTION 

China dispatched 5 warships to a disputed area of the East China Sea surrounding the Chunxiao gas fields . Another Chinese ship violated Japanese waters in the area 2 months later. Both China and Japan claim the area for its rich gas resources. First day of dispute was on 9/9/2005 and last day of dispute was on 11/11/2005.

MID4478
rivalry=710740 nationa=CHINA nationb=JAPAN MID4478 20070428-20070527 
 revtype1a=NOT APPLICABLE revtype2a=NOT APPLICABLE fatala=NONE fatalpa=0 lhosta=DISPLAY OF FORCE 
 revtype1b=NOT APPLICABLE revtype2b=NOT APPLICABLE fatalb=NONE fatalpb=0
lhostb=NO MILITARIZED ACTION 

Chinese destroyers passed through Taiwanese and Japanese territorial waters and traveled along the east coast of Taiwan. It is unclear what the intended purpose of the incursion was, but it is most likely a show of Chinese naval strength. First day of dispute was on 4/28/2007 and last day of dispute was on 5/27/2007.

MID4489
rivalry=710740 nationa=CHINA nationb=JAPAN MID4489 20100421-20100421 
 revtype1a=NOT APPLICABLE revtype2a=NOT APPLICABLE fatala=NONE fatalpa=0 lhosta=DISPLAY OF FORCE 
 revtype1b=NOT APPLICABLE revtype2b=NOT APPLICABLE fatalb=NONE fatalpb=0
lhostb=NO MILITARIZED ACTION 

A Chinese naval helicopter made a flyover around a Japanese destroyer in the waters near Okinawa. First day of dispute was on 4/21/2010 and last day of dispute was on 4/21/2010.

MID4491
rivalry=710740 nationa=JAPAN nationb=CHINA MID4491 20100907-20101128 
 revtype1a=POLICY revtype2a=NOT APPLICABLE fatala=NONE fatalpa=0 lhosta=USE OF FORCE 
 revtype1b=TERRITORY revtype2b=POLICY fatalb=NONE fatalpb=0 lhostb=DISPLAY OF FORCE

Japan and China disputed control of the Senkaku Islands (see MID 4457). China often conducted naval patrols nearby, utilizing naval warships and fishing and civilian activist vessels to harrass Japanese naval forces. At the height of this particular MID, Japan detained and eventually released a Chinese fishing boat captain who rammed his boat into a Japanese patrol boat. First day of dispute was on 9/7/2010 and last day of dispute was on 11/28/2010.

MID3 1993-2001:

MID4061
rivalry=710740 nationa=CHINA nationb=JAPAN MID4061 19950821-19950821 
 revtype1a=TERRITORY revtype2a=NOT APPLICABLE fatala=NONE fatalpa=0 lhosta=DISPLAY OF FORCE 
 revtype1b=NOT APPLICABLE revtype2b=NOT APPLICABLE fatalb=NONE fatalpb=0 lhostb=
DISPLAY OF FORCE 

This dispute consists of two incidents that occurred in the same day when Chinese fighter planes approached the disputed Senkaku Islands and came close to violating Japanese airspace. Japan responded to the action by scrambling two fighters. This dispute consists of two incidents that occurred in the same day when Chinese fighter planes approached the disputed Senkaku Islands and came close to violating Japanese airspace. Japan responded to the action by scrambling two fighters. First and last day of dispute was on 8/21/1995.

MID4062
rivalry=710740 nationa=CHINA nationb=JAPAN MID4062 19960700-19960700 
 revtype1a=TERRITORY revtype2a=NOT APPLICABLE fatala=NONE fatalpa=0 lhosta=DISPLAY OF FORCE 
 revtype1b=NOT APPLICABLE revtype2b=NOT APPLICABLE fatalb=NONE fatalpb=0 lhostb=
NO MILITARIZED ACTION 

This dispute consists of one incident - the Chinese deployment of two submarines to the Senkaku Islands. The Senkakus are an island group that was returned to Japan in 1972, but are claimed by China. The deployment occurred following recent activities by ultra-nationalist groups on the islands. This dispute consists of one incident - the Chinese deployment of two submarines to the Senkaku Islands. The Senkakus are an island group that was returned to Japan in 1972, but are claimed by China. The deployment occurred following recent activities by ultranationalist groups on the islands. First and last day of dispute was on 7/00/1996.

MID4180
rivalry=710740 nationa=CHINA nationb=JAPAN MID4180 19990514-19990715 
 revtype1a=TERRITORY revtype2a=NOT APPLICABLE fatala=NONE fatalpa=0 lhosta=DISPLAY OF FORCE 
 revtype1b=NOT APPLICABLE revtype2b=NOT APPLICABLE fatalb=NONE fatalpb=0 lhostb=
NO MILITARIZED ACTION 

This dispute consists of two incidents in which Chinese naval forces conducted naval exercises around the disputed Senkaku Islands. In the May 1999 incident, Japanese patrols spotted 12 Chinese warships cruising in waters around the Senkaku Islands, within Japan's exclusive economic zone. In the July 1999 incident 10 Chinese vessels were sighted near the Senkakus conducting drills. This dispute occurred within Japan's exclusive economic zone. First day of dispute was on 5/14/1999 and last day of dispute was on 7/15/1999.

RIVNOTES: 

RIV1297, i.e., MID2966, was combined into RIV11298 from 1978 through 1999-, MID4061, MID4062, and MID4180 in riv510 dataset. The later two rivalries are combined because the issue that Japan and China fight over remains consistent throughout both rivalries. They engaged in four disputes over the Senkaku Islands from 1978 through 1999. The rivalry that takes place prior to 1958-RIV1296-has a different character. The central issue motivating this longer rivalry (1873-1958) is Japanese expansion onto the Asian mainland particularly into China. Thus, there are two distinct periods in the rivalry that suggests that there should be two rivalries-one pre 1958 and one post 1958. 

RIV30 eliminated in riv500 dataset because disputes have been incorporated in other rivalries: 

NARRATIVE-CM:
Japanese troops intervened to protect its legation in Peking during the Boxer rebellion beginning on May 31, 1900, including some 10,000 Japanese troops that entered Peking to relieve the foreign legations on August 15, 1900. China and Japan signed a peace agreement on September 12, 1901. Japanese troops entered Chinese territory on September 2, 1914. Japanese troops seized Kiaochow (Jiaozhou) in Shantung province on November 7, 1914. Japan presented the "Twenty-one Demands" to China on January 18, 1915, including demands for recognition of Japanese gains in Shantung province and special privileges and concessions in Manchuria. China agreed to the Japanese demands on May 25, 1915. 

Japan transferred control of the Kiaochow-Tsinan rail line to China on January 23, 1923. Japanese troops were deployed in Shantung province on May 28, 1927, and the Chinese nationalist government protested the troop deployment on May 29, 1927. Japanese troops completed their withdrawal from Shantung province on September 8, 1927. Japan deployed some 5,000 troops in the Shantung province to protect a railway zone on April 20, 1928. The Chinese nationalist government protested the deployment of Japanese troops in Shantung province on April 21, 1928. Japanese and Chinese nationalist troops led by General Chiang Kai-shek clashed in Tsinanfu on May 3-5, 1928. The Japanese government decided to deploy some 18,000 troops in Shantung province on May 8, 1928. Japanese troops occupied Tsinanfu on May 11, 1928. The Chinese nationalist government referred the matter to the *League of Nations* (LON) secretary-general on May 11, 1928. On July 20, 1928, the Chinese nationalist government unilaterally abrogated the *Sino-Japanese Treaty*, which was signed by the countries on July 21, 1896. Japan rejected the abrogation of the treaty on July 31, 1928. Chinese nationalist and Japanese representatives held negotiations in Nanking beginning on October 19, 1928. Chinese and Japanese representatives signed an agreement on March 28, 1929, and Japanese troops withdrew from Shantung province on May 20, 1929. Japanese troops and Chinese troops clashed near Mukden on September 18, 1931. China referred the matter to the LON Council on September 21, 1931. Japanese troops occupied Manchuria. Aristide Briand, president of the LON Council, appealed for a ceasefire on October 9, 1931. The LON Council appealed for the withdrawal of Japanese troops from Manchuria on October 24, 1931. Aristide Briand, president of the LON Council, appealed for the cessation of military hostilities on November 6, 11, and 25, 1931. The LON Council established a five-member commission of inquiry (Britain, Italy, France, Germany, United States) chaired by Lord Earl Lytton of Britain on December 10, 1931. Chinese and Japanese troops clashed near Shanghai on January 18-20, 1932, and Japan deployed some 20,000 troops in Shanghai on January 24, 1932. Japanese troops attacked the Chapei and Hongkew districts of Shanghai on January 28-29, 1932. China referred the matter to the LON Council on January 29, 1932. Britain and the US mediated a ceasefire on January 30, 1932, but Japanese warships attacked Nanking on February 1, 1932. Britain and the US proposed a settlement of the dispute on February 2, 1932, but the proposal was rejected by Japan on February 4, 1932. Japan unilaterally declared the independence of Manchuria from China on February 18, 1932. Admiral Howard Kelly of Britain began mediation efforts on February 28, 1932, and the parties signed a ceasefire agreement in Shanghai on May 5, 1932. Japan completed its troop withdrawal from Shanghai on May 31, 1932. Some 4,274 Chinese troops and 634 Japanese troops were killed during the conflict. The LON commission of inquiry issued a report to the LON Council on October 2, 1932. The report indicated that Japanese actions in Manchuria were not in self-defense as Japan had claimed, and recommended that the parties negotiate a peaceful resolution of the dispute. Japan had declared the independence of Manchukuo on February 18, 1932, and placed Pu Yi (former Emperor of China) on the throne of the country. Japan demanded the withdrawal of Chinese troops from the Jehol province on February 22, 1933, but China rejected the demand on February 24, 1933. The LON Assembly adopted the *Lytton Commission* report on February 24, 1933. Some 30,000 Japanese troops occupied the Jehol province on March 5, 1933. Japan announced its decision to withdraw from the LON on March 27, 1933. Japanese troops occupied parts of the Chahar province on March 30, 1933. China and Japan agreed to a ceasefire in Tang Ku on May 31, 1933. Chinese and Japanese representatives held negotiations in Nanking beginning on September 15, 1936. Chinese and Japanese representatives ended negotiations in Nanking on December 3, 1936. Chinese troops and Japanese troops resumed military hostilities on July 7, 1937, when Japanese troops initiated an incident near the Marco Polo Bridge near Peking. Some 160,000 Japanese troops invaded China on July 8, 1937. Japanese troops captured Tientsin on July 30, 1937 and Peking on July 31, 1937. Some 200,000 Japanese troops commanded by General Iwane Matsui attacked Shanghai on August 8, 1937, and captured the city on November 9, 1937. Some 240,000 Chinese and 80,000 Japanese soldiers were killed or wounded during the battle for Shanghai. China referred the matter of Japanese aggression to the LON Council on September 12, 1937. The United States announced its neutrality in the conflict, and imposed military sanctions (arms embargo) against the countries on September 14, 1937. The LON Assembly condemned Japanese aggression against China on September 28, 1937. The LON Assembly expressed support for China and condemned Japan on October 6, 1937. The US condemned Japan on October 6, 1937. Japanese troops captured Nanking on December 13-14, 1937, resulting in the massacre of some 100,000 Chinese civilians. Japanese troops captured Canton on October 21, 1937 and Hankow on October 25, 1937. Germany mediated negotiations between Chinese and Japanese representatives from November 5, 1937 to January 16, 1938. The LON Council condemned Japan for the use of poison gas in China on May 14, 1938. Japan established a pupet government headed by Wang Ching-wei in Nanking on March 30, 1940. The Chinese government headed by General Chiang Kai-shek declared war against Japan on December 9, 1941. The US provided military assistance to the Chinese government beginning in December 1941. Some 6,800 Chinese and 1,500 Japanese troops were killed in fighting in western Hunan from April to June 6, 1945. Some 3 million Chinese and 500,000 Japanese were killed during the conflict. China claimed the Senkaku (Diaoyu) Islands on December 30, 1971. Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka of Japan and Prime Minister Chou Enlai of China held negotiations in Beijing on September 25-30, 1972. Chinese and Japanese representatives signed an agreement on September 30, 1972, which provided for the establishment of diplomatic relations between the countries. Chinese and Japanese representatives signed a treaty of peace and friendship on August 12, 1978.

SOURCES-CM: 
Allock et al., 1992, 438-439; Brecher and Wilkenfeld, 1997, 150-157; Clodfelter, 1992, 643-644, 660-668; Dennett, 1923; Harding 27-32; http://en.wikipedia.org; http://www.indiana.edu/~league; Jansen 1975;*Keesing*, October 14-21, 1972; Langer, 1972, 1106-1114, 1338-1339; Liu, 1949, 157-171; New York Times; Onwar.com; Pletcher, 1962; Savada, 1994; *Survey of International Affairs *(SIA), 1928, 449-455, 1931, 512-515, 1932, 590-592, 1933, 579-580, 1936, 942-944, 1937 (vol.1), 257-317, 611-613; Times of London; Wainhouse, 1966, 53-64; Worden, Savada, and Dolan, 1988; Yahuda, 236-243. 

NARRATIVE-CR:
The rivalry between China and Japan has two phases. The first has a number of proximate causes but the issue at stake in the rivalry is the Japanese imperial expansion onto the Chinese mainland. The second phase of the rivalry is in the years after World War II. In this phase, Japan is severely limited in the activities it can pursue having been defeated in the war. China on the other hand has replaced Japan as the regional hegemon and disputes the Japanese claim to an island chain between the two countries. This more minor set of disputes in terms of level of hostility and the frequency of disputes is what makes up the second phase of the rivalry which has not yet concluded. 

Phase I:

MID2199 occurred in June of 1873. In 1871, a Japanese ship wrecked off the coast of Formosa. Over fifty Japanese sailors were able to make it ashore on Formosa, but were soon after decapitated by the aboriginals living on the island. The Japanese retaliated by threatening to annex Formosa. The Chinese who maintained sovereignty over the island, acquiesced and agreed to pay compensation for the deaths. MID1489 is titled the Formosan expedition and I believe this dispute is related to MID2199 but the two are not coded as linked in the MID3.021 dataset. I was not able to find direct reference to mutual displays of force between China and Japan (and Japanese use of force) during the period of this dispute (April through December of 1874). 

MID2200 or the Occupation of Ryukyu Islands occurred from March through December of 1875. The Ryukyu Kingdom was once an independent kingdom. In the 1600s, it obtained status as an offshoot of the Chinese empire. A 1609 expedition from Satsuma captured the Kingdom. After that, the kings of the Ryukyus paid tribute to the Japanese emperor as well as the Chinese emperor. In 1875, the Meiji government in Japan forcibly occupied the island group. 

MID2201 or the Annexation of Ryukyu Islands occurred in 1879. In 1879, the Meiji government announced the annexation of the Ryukyus. China objected and the ex-President of the United States Ulysses S. Grant was asked to arbitrate. He decided that Japan's claim to the islands was stronger and ruled in Japan's favor.

MID2202 or the Korean Mutiny occurred from July 31-August 28 1882. This is also referred to as the Imo Soldiers Mutiny. This mutiny occurred in Seoul and resulted in the deaths of several Japanese diplomats and officers. The Chinese garrisoned troops in Seoul in response. 

MID1486 is called the Korean Coup attempt and occurred from 12/4/1884 until 4/18/1885. A small group of politically frustrated Korean aristocrats in the early 1880s came under the influence of a Japanese educator, Fukuzawa Yukichi. This group of Koreans saw themselves as the forefront of Korea's "enlightenment' and advocated for release from Chinese control of Korea. This group led by Kim Ok-kyun were impressed by the Meiji Restoration. They sought to stage a coup d'etat in 1884 with about 200 Japanese legation soldiers. Resident Chinese troops quickly suppressed it. 

MID1488 occurred in October and November of 1885 and it is called the `Korean Invasion Rumor'. Korea requested American officers to train its troops, but Dennett (1923) states that this request was never granted. There was naval action by the British and Russians in April 1885, in an effort to deter the Japanese from invading. 

MID1490 is called the Sino-Japanese War and it occurred from June 5 1894 until March 30 1895. Japan and China fought the first Sino-Japanese War during 1894 and 1895, primarily over control of Korea. Korea had traditionally been a tributary state to China. In 1875 the Qing Dynasty of China had allowed Japan to recognize Korea as an independent state. However, China continued to try to assert influence over Korea, and public opinion in Korea split, with conservatives wanting to retain a close relationship with China while reformists wanted Korea to modernize and to have a closer relationship with Japan. Following the assassination of a pro-Japanese reformist in 1894, a Korean religious sect, the Tonghak, began the Tonghak Peasant Revolution. The Korean government requested help from China in suppressing it. When China contributed assistance, the Japanese government sent an expedition in support of the reformists, and had seized the royal palace in Seoul by June 8, 1894. War between Japan and China was officially declared on August 1, 1894, though some naval fighting had already taken place. The more modern Japanese army defeated the Chinese in a series of battles around Seoul and Pyongyang, forcing them north, and by November 21 the Japanese had taken Port Arthur (now known as Lushun). The Japanese navy devastated China's northern fleet off the mouth of the Yalu River at the Battle of Yalu on September 17, 1894. The Chinese fleet lost 8 out of 12 warships, retreated behind the fortifications of the Weihaiwei naval base, and was then caught by a surprise Japanese land attack across the Liaodong Peninsula, which shattered the ships in harbour with shelling from the landward side. After Weihaiwei's fall on February 2 and an easing of harsh winter conditions, Japanese troops pressed their advance into Manchuria. Faced with these repeated defeats China signed the Treaty of Shimonoseki in April, 1895.

MID31 is the Boxer Rebellion that occurred from May through August of 1900. Conservative opponents of reform in China gave clandestine backing to the anti-foreign and anti-Christian movement of secret societies known as Yihetuan (Society of Righteousness and Harmony). The movement has been better known in the West as the Boxers (from an earlier name-Yihequan, Righteousness and Harmony Boxers). In 1900, Boxer bands spread over the north China countryside, burning missionary facilities and killing Chinese Christians. Finally, in June 1900, the Boxers besieged the foreign concessions in Beijing and Tianjin, an action that provoked an allied relief expedition by the offended nations that included the Japan. The Qing declared war against the invaders. The insurgents finally fell to an international force eventually numbering 45,000 Japanese, United States, Austro-Hungarian, British, French, German, Italian, Russian and anti-Boxer Chinese troops, which captured Tianjing on July 14 and Beijing on August 14. Under the Protocol of 1901, ten officials of the rebellion were executed and hundreds more were punished. The Legation Quarter was expanded and the Chinese were made to pay war reparations and agreed to the stationing of foreign troops in China. 

MID2203 or the `South Manchurian Railroad' occurred in October and November of 1907. Here the South Manchurian Railroad refused to deliver Chinese mail unless it was sent through the Japanese post. The South Manchuria Railway Company was founded by Japan in 1906, after the Russo-Japanese War (1904-1905), and operated in Japanese-occupied Manchuria. From 1906 or 1910 until 1925, the company also operated the Korean railway system. This company developed soy beans and mineral resources and brought to Japan by its railway. It also built hotels, schools, libraries, etc for Japanese immigrants. It was occupied by the Soviet army in 1945.

MID2204 or `Chiento-South Manchuria Railroad' occurred from April to September of 1909. Here the Japanese attempted to work out an arrangement whereby the Chinese would cooperate with the administration of a military railway in China that Japan controlled. The Chinese delayed which caused friction and clashes during negotiations to resolve the dispute. 

MID260 occurred from 9/26/1914 to 9/25/1915 and is called the twenty one demands. Seizing the opportunity of Berlin's distraction with the European War and wanting to expand its sphere of influence in China, Japan declared war on Germany in August 1914 and quickly occupied German-leased territories in China's Shandong Province and the Mariana, Caroline, and Marshall islands in the Pacific. With its Western allies heavily involved in the war in Europe, Japan sought further to consolidate its position in China by presenting the Twenty-One Demands to China in January 1915. Besides expanding its control over the German holdings, Manchuria, and Inner Mongolia, Japan also sought joint ownership of a major mining and metallurgical complex in central China, prohibitions on China's ceding or leasing any coastal areas to a third power, and miscellaneous other political, economic, and military controls, which, if achieved, would have reduced China to a Japanese protectorate. In the face of slow negotiations with the Chinese government, widespread anti-Japanese sentiments in China, and international condemnation, Japan withdrew the final group of demands, and treaties were signed in May 1915. Japan made it clear to China that if she did not agree to the modified list of demands Japan would make war on China. 

MID2205 or the Zhengjiatun Incident occurred from August 1, 1916 until April 13 of 1917. This is a minor incident in which some Chinese soldiers assaulted a Japanese policeman. The Japanese retaliated and several soldiers on both sides were killed. 

MID1777 or `Chinese Eastern railroad II' occurred from April of 1918 until July 19, 1919. The events during this dispute are those that coincide with World War I. China is not coded as a participant in World War I thus, the separate dispute here. Japan took the opportunity of the War in Europe to press its claims in China during the first World War. At this point, Japan was extending its imperial claims in China and the war among the Great Powers in Europe provided a significant distraction to the European states. Japan pursued its claim to territorial rights to railroads linking territory under Japanese control. 

MID2701 occurred in August, September, and November of 1919. This dispute is titled the `Chinese attempt to navigate the Amur river III.' Despite the specificity of the title of this dispute, I was not able to locate information on this dispute. 

MID1810 or the Fuzhuou incident occurred in December of 1919. I was not able to locate specific information regarding a dispute related to Fuzhou. 

MID2206 or `Chientao' occurred from June through October of 1920. This dispute is a dispute in which Japan is forcibly occupying portions of the Chinese mainland near Chientao. 

MID2207 or the Anti-Mukden Rebellion occurred in December of 1925. Here, the Chinese factions were engaged in heavy fighting near Mukden. A Chinese General, Yang Yu-tang, agreed to a deal with the Japanese in which they would provide troops to assist the Nationalist forces in the civil war with the Communist troops. 

MID2208 is called `Dagu (Taku) Harbor' and occurred March 15-18, 1926. This is a multilateral mid involving Germany, China, Japan, France, the UK, the US, the USSR and Italy. In this incident, the Great Powers demanded that China de-mine the Dagu Harbor as it provided access to a major river into China. The Great Powers jointly threatened military action if China did not acquiesce. China and Japan engaged in naval hostilities in which several seamen were killed on both sides during this period. 

MID145 occurred from January until March of 1927. Chinese Communists seized Nanjing (Nanking) and killed six foreigners in an attempt to discredit Chiang Kai-Sheik and the Nationalists. The international community raised a force of 40,000 troops to protect Shanghai. The nations that contributed to the troop deployments were: the UK, the USA, Japan, Italy, Portugal, Spain and France. 

MID2209 is called the Hankow incident and it occurred on April 2 and 3 of 1927. Here a minor incident occurred when Japanese sailors fired on a group of Chinese mobbing shops in Hankow. 

MID2210 or the Occupation of Tsinan occurred from May through August of 1927. 
The Japanese government dispatched troops to protect residents in Jinan (Tsinan), hindering the advance of Kuo Min Tang forces marching on Beijing.

MID40 occurred from 4/10/1928 until 11/18/1928 and is called the Tsinan Clash. Nationalist Chinese troops fought with Japanese soldiers from Jinan (Tsinan) during the Nationalist offensive against Beijing. The Japanese government dispatched forces to Shantung in response to Nationalist Chinese preparations for an offensive into northern China. The Japanese temporarily seized control of the Chinese railways.

MID129 is the Manchurian War. This dispute took place from 9/18/1931 until 5/31/1935. It began with the Mukden Incident. Japanese Army conspirators blew up a few meters of South Manchurian Railway Company track near Mukden (now Shenyang), and blamed it on Chinese saboteurs, and used the event as an excuse to seize Mukden. Japanese forces then attacked Shanghai in January 1932 on the pretext of Chinese resistance in Manchuria. Finding stiff Chinese resistance in Shanghai, the Japanese waged a three-month undeclared war there before a truce was reached in March 1932. Several days later, Manchukuo was established. Manchukuo was a Japanese puppet state headed by the last Chinese emperor, Puyi, as chief executive and later emperor. The civilian government in Tokyo was powerless to prevent these military happenings. Instead of being condemned, the Japanese Army's actions enjoyed popular support back home. International reactions were extremely negative, however. Japan withdrew from the League of Nations, and the United States became increasingly hostile. From 1933 to 1935, Japanese forces invaded Chahar and Jehol, in Inner Mongolia, claiming it as a part of Manchuria (January-March); the Chinese were forced to withdraw from Tientsin. MID2211 (the Chahar Occupation) and MID139 (Jehol) also took place in this period and were a part of the general Japanese expansion onto the Asian mainland. 

MID2212 occurred from 5/20/1935 until 6/10/1935 and is called the Ho-Umetsu Agreement. This dispute is related to MID2213 that occurred from 6/13/1935 until 6/27/1935. It is called the China Daihara Agreemen. Both of these diputes are about Japanese concern for guaranteeing their positions gained in the war with China. The Japanese Army felt that they did not want to show any partiality with either the Communists or the Nationalists who were fighting amongst themselves within China. The Army felt that they should maintain neutrality in accordance with an earlier agreement, the Tangku Truce of 1933. The conditions of this agreement were Chinese withdrawals from Japanese occupied territory in the north. Local Japanese commanders however did not feel comfortable with this and Generals Ho-Umetshu and Doihara made separate agreements with local Chinese Kuomintang commanders. In so doing, they used force in efforts to ensure the agreements were favorable to the Japanese position in the agreements. 

MID616 occurred in November of 1935. During November, Japan increased its land grab in China and took over five Northern provinces (Shantung, Hopei, Shansi, Suiyuan and Chahar). The Japanese had in mind the same aims they did when they established Manchuko in Manchuria: control of the territory with a puppet regime and significant autonomy granted to the local leaders. 

MID2214 began on 7/10/1935 with a clash of troops in a Chinese park over shooting practice and lasted throughout the year. This conflict was Japanese aggression towards Chinese on the mainland in their efforts to take Chinese territory. During this period of conflict the Chinese notably had difficulty uniting against the Japanese and at one point Chiang Kai Check was captured by the one faction of his army and forced to agree to a unified Nationalist/Communist campaign against the Japanese. 

MID157 or the Marco Polo Bridge Incident occurred on July 7, 1937 and is coded as lasting until December of 1941. The conflict here is a war between Japan and China that is also referred to as the Sino-Japanese War. It is coded as a war in the MID dataset. During night maneuvers, Japanese troops clashed with Chinese forces at Lukouchiao, near Beijing. The fighting quickly spread to other parts of China, which reflected Japanese preparations for a general war with China. The Japanese government did not declare war against China for technical reasons of international law. China and Japan formally declare war against each other after the attack on Pearl Harbor on December 7, 1941. The dispute is coded as terminated on December 7, 1941 at which point both states mutually enter World War II opposed to one another. 

MID258 is World War II. 

Phase II:

The 1951 Treaty of San Francisco formally ended Japan's involvement in World War Two. This treaty was not signed the the PRC as it was excluded from the treaty negotiations and the subsequent signing by the United States. Formally, the state of war was not ended until 1972 when Japan extended diplomatic relations to the PRC. In practice, however, Japan began to restore relations with China almost immediately following the signing of Treaty of San Francisco in spite of the reservations of the United States. An informal trade agreement was signed by both Japan and the PRC on June 1, 1952. While in September of 1952 Japan joined CHINCOM, the US committee to limit trade with the PRC, the Japanese Diet passed a unanimous resolution in July of 1953 calling for closer economic relations with the PRC. Between 1952 and 1958 four unofficial trade agreements were signed between the PRC and Japan. In 1958 relations suffered when Kishi Nobusake, a former member of the wartime government, visited Taiwan. In 1962, Japan and China formally agreed to classify trade between the two states into two categories. The second of these categories "Memorandum Trade" established offices in the two capitals which served as de facto missions between the countries until formal recognition in 1972. In 1978, China and Japan signed a "treaty of peace and friendship" that formally set aside past grievances. 

In spite of these cooperative efforts between the two states, there are a number of disputes between the two countries in the years after World War II. The character of the disputes between the two countries changed considerably however. Japan was occupied by the United States for a number of years. The issues in the disputes following World War II are all about territorial control of the Senkaku islands and the fishing waters associated with them. Thus, it seems that the disputes that follow the war constitute a new phase in the rivalry. The rivalry is no longer about Japanese regional hegemony but of Chinese regional hegemony and disputes over territory. 

MID3208 occurred from 12/14/1953 to 7/4/1954. The issue in this period was one of access to fishing waters. The Japanese pursued access to fishing areas adjacent to China. The Japanese came within ten miles of the Chinese coast. In an effort to brush the Japanese back, the PRC seized and fired on a number of Japanese fishing boats during this period. Three specific incidents are described below. On 12/15/1953, a fleet of PRC gunboats fired on four Japanese ships Southwest of Korea and seized one Japanese trawler. On 3/14/1954, a PRC patrol boat fired on a Japanese fishing boat that was fishing ten miles off the coast of Chekiang. On 7/4/1954, the PRC seized four Japanese fishing boats of the coast of Shanghai. 

MID2853 occurred on 5/7/1958. The PRC seized fourteen Japanese fishing boats with 170 fishermen aboard. The PRC claimed that these boats were encroaching on PRC fishing waters. The New York Times reported that the issue at hand was disagreement over the details of a bilateral trade agreement between the two countries. An issue noted was whether the PRC could fly the Red Chinese flag over its trade mission office in Tokyo. 

MID2966 occurred on 4/13/1978. This dispute was a display of force by the Chinese. The issue at stake in this dispute was territorial control of the Senkaku Island chain. The Chinese sent 38 fishing boats into the disputed waters to anchor and attempt to assert control over the region. The fisherman had small arms and displayed them to Japanese patrol boats that passed. 

MID4061 occurred on 8/21/1995. This dispute consists of two incidents that occurred in the same day when Chinese fighter planes approached the disputed Senkaku Islands and came close to violating Japanese airspace. Japan responded to the action by scrambling two fighters. This dispute consists of two incidents that occurred in the same day when Chinese fighter planes approached the disputed Senkaku Islands and came close to violating Japanese airspace. Japan responded to the action by scrambling two fighters.

MID4062 occurred in July of 1996. This dispute consists of one incident-the Chinese deployment of two submarines to the Senkaku Islands. The Senkakus are an island group that was returned to Japan in 1972, but are claimed by China. The deployment occurred following recent activities by ultra-nationalist groups on the islands. This dispute consists of one incident-the Chinese deployment of two submarines to the Senkaku Islands. The Senkakus are an island group that was returned to Japan in 1972, but are claimed by China. The deployment occurred following recent activities by ultra-nationalist groups on the islands.

MID4180 occurred from May 14 until July 15 1999. This dispute consists of two incidents in which Chinese naval forces conducted naval exercises around the disputed Senkaku Islands. In the May 1999 incident, Japanese patrols spotted 12 Chinese warships cruising in waters around the Senkaku Islands, within Japan's exclusive economic zone. In the July 1999 incident 10 Chinese vessels were sighted near the Senkakus conducting drills. This dispute occurred within Japan's exclusive economic zone.

SOURCES-CR:
Allock et al., 1992, 438-439; Brecher and Wilkenfeld, 1997, 150-157; Clodfelter, 1992, 643-644, 660-668; Dennett, 1923; Harding 27-32; http://en.wikipedia.org; http://www.indiana.edu/~league; Jansen 1975;*Keesing*, October 14-21, 1972; Langer, 1972, 1106-1114, 1338-1339; Liu, 1949, 157-171; New York Times; Onwar.com; Pletcher, 1962; Savada, 1994; *Survey of International Affairs *(SIA), 1928, 449-455, 1931, 512-515, 1932, 590-592, 1933, 579-580, 1936, 942-944, 1937 (vol.1), 257-317, 611-613; Times of London; Wainhouse, 1966, 53-64; Worden, Savada, and Dolan, 1988; Yahuda, 236-243. 

SB-CR:
China (People's Republic of China) / Japan Years: 1874-1951 Issues at stake: Japanese presence on Asian mainland, including Manchuria and Korea; control of Formosa and Ryuku islands. End coding: On September 8, 1951, Japan signed the Treaty of San Francisco, affirming the terms of its 1945 surrender, giving up any claims to the Chinese mainland or to special status in China. Number of reciprocated 30 day militarized disputes: 11. Last militarized dispute: 1945 (WWII). Wars: 1894-1895, 1900, 1931-1933, 1937-1941, 1941-1945. Summary: While the specific stakes of the Sino-Japanese conflict have been various pieces of territory, the rivalry can somewhat more generally be thought of as over who is the predominant Asian power. The start of the rivalry dates to a dispute over Formosa and the Ryuku Islands. Disputes over the Ryuku islands continued through the late 1800s, and tension over influence in Korea grew with a Japanese-sponsored coup attempt in Korea in 1885. Korean tensions escalated to the Sino-Japanese war of 1894-1895, in which Japan captured Port Arthur (in Manchuria) and most of Korea but was forced to withdraw by Britain, France, and Russia. Japan recaptured Korea and extended its control in Manchuria in the Russo-Japanese war of 1904-1905, and formally incorporated Korea in 1910. Disputes between China and Japan continued through WWII, with Japanese intervention in the Chinese civil war of 1927 and repeated attempts by the Japanese to extend their empire in Manchuria. The rivalry between Japan and China ends only after Japanese defeat in WWII. The 1945 armistice agreement limited Japanese sovereignty to Honshu, Hokkaido, Kyushu, Shikoku and some minor islands, and stated that the USSR would administer the Kurile islands and the southern part of Sakhalin island (leading to the ongoing rivalry between Japan and USSR, above). In the final WWII peace treaty with Japan, the 1951 Treaty of San Francisco, Japan renounced control of all of the territories it surrendered in the 1945 armistice, and explicitly renounced any "special rights" in China. Since 1951, Japan has not dispute any Chinese claims to the areas (Korea, Manchuria, Formosa) that were previously in dispute. In 1952 the Nationalist Chinese government on Taiwan/Formosa signed a separate peace treaty with Japan reaffirming the 1951 settlement. The People's Republic of China did not sign the 1951 treaty, as neither the PRC nor the ROC were invited to the San Francisco peace conference. Diplomatic relations between China and Japan were not restored until 1972, and in 1978 Japan and the PRC signed a Treaty of Peace and Friendship. However, because the Japanese gave up all claim to the issues in dispute in the 1951 treaty, and because no disputes after 1945 over those issues occurred, I code 1951 as the end date of the Sino-Japanese rivalry. Notes: In 1978 the COW dispute data set shows a minor dispute over the Senkaku islands, followed by the 1978 signing of the Treaty of Peace and Friendship between Japan and the PRC. The 1951 Peace Treaty is used because the islands were not a central part of the issues at stake earlier in the rivalry. Additionally, there were no disputes related to those islands between 1945 and 1978. COW also has minor disputes in 1953 and 1958. Both of these involved the seizure of fishing boats which were quickly released, and not related to territorial claims by either side. Sources: Grenville (1974), Kinder and Hilgemann (1978).

PS-NARRATIVE: 

19510908-19610207 Transition

In the final WWII peace treaty with Japan, the 1951 Treaty of San Francisco, Japan renounced control of all of the territories it surrendered in the 1945 armistice, and explicitly renounced any "special rights" in China. The Treaty was signed on September 8, 1951, in San Francisco. Since 1951, Japan has not dispute any Chinese claims to the areas (Korea, Manchuria, Formosa) that were previously in dispute. In 1952 the Nationalist Chinese government on Taiwan/Formosa signed a separate peace treaty with Japan reaffirming the 1951 settlement. The People's Republic of China did not sign the 1951 treaty, as neither the PRC nor the ROC were invited to the San Francisco peace conference. Nevertheless the treaty directly impacted China's foreign policy. The last MID of RIV1296 ended on May 7, 1958. On February 8, 1961, China and Japan re-started their trade relations after a 18 months break. The level of bilateral trade was still minimal, but Japan's Diet suggested that relations should be enlarged as it was a matter of time before China will be accepted as a member of the United Nations.

Two minor MIDs occurred in the 1950s. MID3208 occurred from 12/14/1953 to 7/4/1954. The issue in this period was one of access to fishing waters. The Japanese pursued access to fishing areas adjacent to China. The Japanese came within ten miles of the Chinese coast. In an effort to brush the Japanese back, the PRC seized and fired on a number of Japanese fishing boats during this period. Three specific incidents are described below. On 12/15/1953, a fleet of PRC gunboats fired on four Japanese ships Southwest of Korea and seized one Japanese trawler. On 3/14/1954, a PRC patrol boat fired on a Japanese fishing boat that was fishing ten miles off the coast of Chekiang. On 7/4/1954, the PRC seized four Japanese fishing boats of the coast of Shanghai. 

MID2853 occurred on 5/7/1958. The PRC seized fourteen Japanese fishing boats with 170 fishermen aboard. The PRC claimed that these boats were encroaching on PRC fishing waters. The New York Times reported that the issue at hand was disagreement over the details of a bilateral trade agreement between the two countries. An issue noted was whether the PRC could fly the Red Chinese flag over its trade mission office in Tokyo. 

19610208-20159999 RIV11298-0.25

On December 5, 1964, Japan's Prime Minister, Eisaku Sato, pledged the need to improve relations with China. However, the Chinese state-run media called this as a propaganda stunt. Nevertheless, an official Chinese trade representative signed a significant amount of deals with Japanese industrialists worth several billion dollars. It was estimated that the trade between Japan and China will amount to 150 million USD each way in 1965, an increase of 25 million from 1964. China accused Japan for offering US the possibility to have nuclear bases in Japan in 1966. Despite the accusations trade continued to increase. On April 18, 1970, China and Japan announced to have reached an accord on their semi-official trade treaty. On September 29, 1972 China and Japan signed Joint Statement on normalization of the bilateral relations. On September 29, 1972, China and Japan signed an agreement to establish diplomatic relations. The agreement also established trade relations between the two countries. In the years between 1972 and 1978 a large number of trade agreements were signed between the countries on such issues as steel trade, fuel and other commodities. On January 5, 1974, China and Japan signed a trade agreement in Beijing. On April 18, 1975, the mixed trade committee between China and Japan opens its first joint meeting in Beijing. On February 16, 1978, China and Japan sign a long-term trade agreement in Beijing. On February 16, 1978, China and Japan signed a USD $20 billion trade pact in Beijing that set the scene for marked improvements in their diplomatic and political relations and is a welcome economic plum for Japan. For Japan, the major eight-year pact, which is an agreement between China's government and a group of Japanese industrialists, allows it a head start into China's vast market.

MID2966 occurred on 4/13/1978. This dispute was a display of force by the Chinese. The issue at stake in this dispute was territorial control of the Senkaku Island chain. The Chinese sent 38 fishing boats into the disputed waters to anchor and attempt to assert control over the region. The fisherman had small arms and displayed them to Japanese patrol boats that passed. On July 20, 1978, it was announced that a new era was opened in the Sino-Japanese relations. The two countries which remained at arms' length for 29 years following the 1949 revolution in China were currently planning a mass of joint industrial projects. On August 12, 1978, the Chinese Foreign Minister Huang Hua and his Japanese counterpart Sunao Sonoda signed the Treaty of Peace and Friendship Between the People's Republic of China and Japan. On October 22-29, 1978, the Chinese Vice Premier Deng Xiaoping visited Japan. China and Japan exchanged instruments of ratification of the Treaty of Peace and Friendship between the People's Republic of China and Japan on October 23, 1978. The treaty formally becomes effective.

On June 1, 1979, the Sino-Japanese relations have noticeably deteriorated over the Senkaku Islands dispute. This deterioration has been triggered off by Japan's construction of a heliport on Uotsuri Island and the dispatch of a 31-man survey team there. Peking lost no time in lodging a formal protest with Japan.
